subject: Re: [junit] Repost:  Am I headed in the right direction?
msgSnippet: ... Perhaps there might be an offshoot of JUnit that can automate GUI testing, but in that case, you need a simple scripting language--with the real work done
messageBody:
evought@... wrote:

> I think the real reason it's off the beaten trail is because this code is
> undertested since it usually ends up being a pain. I know that's been the
> case with me. I tend to spend test effort where I am likely to find the
> most bugs with the least work. The common practice seems to be to refactor
> as much of the logic out of the GUI as possible, automate just enough of
> the GUI test for sanity checking, then manually walk through it as part of
> a functional test process. It's *not* entirely satisfactory, but does
> (mostly) work.


Perhaps there might be an offshoot of JUnit that can automate GUI testing,
but in that case, you need a simple scripting language--with the real work
done under the hood. It's kind of like testing a webapp, you have to have
an external program test the critical sections by script--it is inneficient
to do it with direct Java code.

I find that JUnit style testing works best for tests in the microcosm of
individual classes or components. Scripting language based testing works
best for tests in the macrocosm of a running system.

So, again we have to differentiate between *unit* tests and *integration*
tests. Anything with a GUI (webapp or swing app) should be considered
integration testing. JUnit is not suited for integration testing--although
it can be extended in some ways to allow for a certain level of integration
testing (I did this with Avalon component testing framework).

That solution does not necessarily scale well, because sometimes you have
to test what happens when there is interaction between optional components
and if the tested component fails gracefully if a required component is
not available.

My advice: JUnit for unit tests, and some other tool for integration tests.

Both are necessary, and they catch different classes of bugs. While JUnit
works well for a one size fits all unit test, it is rare to find an integration
test framework that fits all situations. That is because the environment
is different for each type of system. For example, Webapps have a very different
environment than Swing based apps, and both environments are very different
from testing a server.
